<verse number="24" style="v" />Those are some of the things that Benaiah did. So he became as famous as the three greatest warriors.

<verse number="25" style="v" />He was more honored that the other members of the group of thirty great warriors, but he did not become a member of the group of three most outstanding warriors. David appointed him to be the leader of his bodyguards.

<para style="b" />

<para style="li1">

<verse number="26" style="v" />These are the names of the great warriors:</para>

<para style="li2">Asahel, the younger brother of Joab;</para>

<para style="li2">Elhanan, the son of Dodo, from Bethlehem;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="27" style="v" />Shammah, from the Harod clan;</para>

<para style="li2">Helez, from the Pelon clan;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="28" style="v" />Ira, the son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa town;</para>

<para style="li2">Abiezer, from Anathoth city;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="29" style="v" />Sibbecai, from Hushah's clan;</para>

<para style="li2">Ilai from Ahoh's clan;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="30" style="v" />Maharai, from Netophah town;</para>

<para style="li2">Heled, the son of Baanah, also from Netophah town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="31" style="v" />Ithai, the son of Ribai, from Gibeah town in the land that belonged to the tribe of Benjamin;</para>

<para style="li2">Benaiah, from Pirathon town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="32" style="v" />Hurai, from the valleys near Gaash mountain;</para>

<para style="li2">Abiel from the clan of Arabah;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="33" style="v" />Azmaveth, from Baharum town;</para>

<para style="li2">Eliahba, from Shaalbon town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="34" style="v" />The sons of Hashem from the Gizon clan;</para>

<para style="li2">Jonathan the son of Shagee from the Harar town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="35" style="v" />Ahiam the son of Sharar;</para>

<para style="li2">Eliphal the son of Ur;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="36" style="v" />Hepher from the Mekerath clan;</para>

<para style="li2">Ahijah from the Pelon clan;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="37" style="v" />Hezro from Carmel city;</para>

<para style="li2">Naarai the son of Ezbai;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="38" style="v" />Joel the younger brother of Nathan;</para>

<para style="li2">Mibhar the son of Hagri;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="39" style="v" />Zelek from the Ammon people-group;</para>

<para style="li2">Naharai, the man who carried Joab's weapons, from Beeroth town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="40" style="v" />Ira and Gareb from Jattir town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="41" style="v" />Uriah, Bathsheba's husband, from the Heth people-group;</para>

<para style="li2">Zabad the son of Ahlai;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="42" style="v" />Adina the son of Shiza, a leader from the tribe of Reuben, who had thirty soldiers with him;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="43" style="v" />Hanan the son of Maacah;</para>

<para style="li2">Joshaphat from Mithna town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="44" style="v" />Uzzia from Ashterath town;</para>

<para style="li2">Shama and Jeiel, the sons of Hotham, from Aroer city;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="45" style="v" />Jediael the son of Shimri</para>

<para style="li2">and his younger brother Joha, from Tiz town;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="46" style="v" />Eliel from Mahavah town;</para>

<para style="li2">Jeribai and Joshaviah, the sons of Elnaam;</para>

<para style="li2">Ithmah from the Moab region;</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="47" style="v" />Eliel and Obed,</para>

<para style="li2">and Jaasiel from Zobah town.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />David went to Ziklag town to escape from King Saul. While he was there, many warriors came and joined him, and they helped him when he fought battles.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />They carried bows and arrows. They were able to shoot arrows and to sling stones. They could use either their right arms or their left arms to do that. They were relatives of Saul from the tribe of Benjamin.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Their leader was Ahiezer. Next in command was Joash. They were both sons of Shemaah from Gibeah city. These are the names of some of those warriors:</para>

<para style="li1">Jeziel and Pelet, the sons of Azmaveth;</para>

<para style="li1">Beracah;</para>

<para style="li1">Jehu from Anathoth town;</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="4" style="v" />Ishmaiah from the Gibeon city, who was the leader of the thirty greatest warriors;</para>

<para style="li1">Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, and Jozabad from Gederah town;</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="5" style="v" />Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, Shemariah, and Shephatiah from Haruph town;</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="6" style="v" />Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer and Jashobeam, who were descendants of Korah;</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="7" style="v" />Joelah and Zebadiah, who were sons of Jeroham, from Gedor town.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Some men from the tribe of Gad east of the Jordan River joined David when he was at his fortress in the caves in the desert. They were brave warriors who were trained for fighting battles and able to use shields and spears well. They .</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />Ezer was their leader.</para>

<para style="li1">Next in command was Obadiah.</para>

<para style="li1">Next was Eliab.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />Next was Mishmannah.</para>

<para style="li1">Next was Jeremiah.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="11" style="v" />Next was Attai.</para>

<para style="li1">Next was Eliel.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="12" style="v" />Next was Johanan.</para>

<para style="li1">Next was Elzabad.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="13" style="v" />Next was another man whose name was Jeremiah.</para>

<para style="li1">The last was Macbannai.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Those men from the tribe of Gad were all army officers. Some of them commanded 1,000 soldiers, and some of them commanded 100 soldiers.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />They crossed to the west side of the Jordan River during March, at the time of the year when the river was flooded. They chased from there all the people who lived in the valleys on both sides of the river.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Some other men from the tribe of Benjamin and from Judah also came to David in his fortress.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />David went out of the cave to meet them and said to them, "If you have come peacefully to help me, I am eager to have to join with me. But if you have come to enable my enemies to capture me, even though I  will see it and condemn, Or: punish you."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Then God's Spirit came upon Amasai, who was the leader of the thirty greatest warriors, and he said,</para>

<para style="q1">"David, we want to be with you;</para>

<para style="q2">you who are the son of Jesse, we will join you.</para>

<para style="q1">We know that things will go very well  for you and for those who are with you,</para>

<para style="q2">because your God is helping you."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="19" style="v" />So David welcomed those men, and he appointed them to be leaders of his soldiers. Some men from the tribe of Manasseh also joined David when he went with the soldiers of Philistia to fight against Saul's army. But David and his men did not really help the army of Philistia. After the leaders of Philistia talked about David and his soldiers, they sent David away. They said, "If David joins his master Saul again, we will all be killed !"

  <verse number="20" style="v" />When David went to Ziklag, these were the men from the tribe of Manasseh who went with him: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, another man whose name was Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai. Each of them had been a commander of 1,000 men in Saul's army.</para>

<verse number="21" style="v" />They were all brave soldiers, and they helped David to fight against the groups of men who roamed throughout the country, robbing people. So those men became commanders in David's army.

<verse number="22" style="v" />Every day more men joined David's men, and his army became large, like .

<para style="p">

  <verse number="23" style="v" />These are the numbers of soldiers who were ready for battle who joined David at Hebron city. They came to help him to become the king of Israel instead of Saul, as Yahweh had promised would happen.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="24" style="v" />There were 6,800 men from Judah, who carried shields and spears.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="25" style="v" />There were 7,100 men from the tribe of Simeon. They were all strong warriors trained to fight battles.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="26" style="v" />There were 4,600 men from the tribe of Levi.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="27" style="v" />Jehoiada, who was a leader descended from Aaron, was in that group of descendants of Levi, and there were 3,700 men with him.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="28" style="v" />Zadok, a strong young soldier, was also in that group, and there were 22 other leaders from his clan who came with him.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="29" style="v" />There were 3,000 men from the tribe of Benjamin who were Saul's relatives. Most of them had previously wanted one of Saul's descendants to be the king.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="30" style="v" />There were 20,800 men from the tribe of Ephraim who were all brave warriors and trained for fighting battles and famous in their own clans.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="31" style="v" />There were 18,000 men from the half of the tribe of Manasseh that lived west of the Jordan River. They were all chosen to go and help David become the king.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="32" style="v" />There were 200 men who were leaders from the tribe of Issachar. They always knew what the Israelites should do, and they knew the right time to do it. Their relatives were with them, commanded by their leaders.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="33" style="v" />There were 55,000 men from the tribe of Zebulun. They were all experienced warriors and knew how to use all kinds of weapons well. They were completely loyal to David.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="34" style="v" />There were 1,000 officers from the tribe of Naphtali. With them were 37,000 soldiers, each carrying shields and spears.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="35" style="v" />There were 28,600 soldiers from the tribe of Dan, all trained to fight battles.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="36" style="v" />There were 47,000 experienced soldiers from the tribe of Asher, all trained to fight battles.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="37" style="v" />There were also 120,000 soldiers from the area east of the Jordan River who joined David. They were from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the eastern half of the tribe of Manasseh. They had all kinds of weapons.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="38" style="v" />All those men were soldiers who volunteered to be in David's army. They came to Hebron wanting very much to enable David to be the king of all of the Israelite people.

  <verse number="39" style="v" />The men spent three days there with David, eating and drinking, because their families had given them food to take with them.

  <verse number="40" style="v" />Also, their fellow Israelites came from as far away as the area where the tribes of Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali lived, bringing food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen. They brought a lot of flour, fig cakes, raisins, wine, olive oil, cattle and sheep. And throughout Israel, the people were very joyful.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />One day David talked with all his army officers. Some of them were commanders of 100 soldiers and some were commanders of 1,000 soldiers.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Then he summoned the other Israelite leaders and said to all of them, "If it seems to you to be a good thing for us to do, and if it is what Yahweh our God wants, let's send a message to our fellow Israelites in all the areas of our country, including the priests and descendants of Levi who are living among them in their towns and in the nearby pasturelands, to come and join us,

  <verse number="3" style="v" />because we want to bring the Sacred Chest of our God back to us. While Saul was the king, we did not go to God's presence to ask him what we should do."

  <verse number="4" style="v" />All the people agreed with David, because they all thought that it was the right thing to do.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />So David gathered all the Israelite people, from the Shihor River in Egypt to Lebo-Hamath town in the north, and told them that he wanted them to help bring the Sacred Chest of God back to Jerusalem from Kiriath-Jearim city.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />David went with all the Israelite people to Baalah town, which is another name for Kiriath-Jearim, to get the Sacred Chest. The people believed that God ruled from between the statues of winged creatures that was above the lid of the Sacred Chest, and the Sacred Chest belongs to Yahweh .</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="7" style="v" />The people put the Sacred Chest on a new cart and carried it from Abinadab's house. Uzzah and Ahio were guiding the oxen that were pulling the cart.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />David and all the Israelite people were celebrating in God's presence. They were singing with all their strength, and playing lyres, harps, tambourines, and cymbals, and blowing trumpets.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />But when David's men came to the place where Kidon threshed grain, the oxen stumbled. So Uzzah reached out with his hand to prevent the Sacred Chest from falling off the cart.

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Yahweh immediately became very angry with Uzzah, and as he was watching, he caused Uzzah to suddenly die there because he had put his hand on the Sacred Chest, and Yahweh had commanded that only the descendants of Levi who help the priests should touch the Sacred Chest.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="11" style="v" />David was angry because Yahweh had punished  Uzzah. And now that place where Uzzah died is called 'The Punishment of Uzzah.'</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />That day, David was afraid of God. He asked himself, "How can I bring God's Sacred Chest to my city? 

  <verse number="13" style="v" />So the men with David did not take the Sacred Chest to Jerusalem. Instead, they took it to the house of Obed-Edom, who was from Gath city.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />The Sacred Chest stayed with Obed-Edom's family in his house for three months. And during that time Yahweh blessed Obed-Edom's family and everything that he owned.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />One day Hiram, the king of Tyre city, sent some messengers to David to talk about making an agreement between their countries. Then Hiram sent cedar logs, bricklayers, and carpenters to build a palace for David.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />When that happened, David knew that Yahweh had truly caused him to be the king of Israel, and that he had caused his kingdom to be greatly respected. Yahweh did this because he loved his Israelite people.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />David married more women in Jerusalem, and those women gave birth to more sons and daughters for him.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />The names of the children that were born to him there in Jerusalem are Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet,

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphelet.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />When the army of Philistia heard that David has been appointed to be king of all of Israel, they went to try to capture him. But David heard that they were coming, so he and his soldiers went out to fight against them.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />The army of Philistia had attacked the people in the Rephaim Valley southwest of Jerusalem and had robbed them.</para>

<verse number="10" style="v" />David asked God, "Should my men and I go and attack the army of Philistia? If we go, will you enable us to defeat [IDI] them?"

<para style="p">Yahweh replied, "Yes, go, and I will enable you to defeat [IDI] them."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="11" style="v" />So David and his men went up to a town where the soldiers of Philistia were staying and defeated the soldiers of Philistia. Then David said, "God has enabled me and my soldiers to overwhelm my enemies like  'Baal-Perazim' which means 'Yahweh breaks through'.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />As the soldiers of Philistia fled, they left their idols there. So David commanded his soldiers to burn those idols.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="13" style="v" />But soon the army of Philistia attacked the people in that valley again.

  <verse number="14" style="v" />So again David prayed to God to ask him what he should do, and God replied, saying "Do not attack the army of Philistia from the front. Instead, go around them, and attack them from the rear in front of the balsam trees.</para>

<verse number="15" style="v" />When you hear something in the tops of the balsam trees that sounds like soldiers marching, attack them. I, God, will have gone ahead of you to enable you to defeat the army of Philistia."

<verse number="16" style="v" />So David did what God commanded him to do, and he and his army defeated the army of Philistia, all the way from Gibeon city west to Gezer city.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />So David became famous in all the nearby countries, and Yahweh caused the leaders of all the nations to be afraid of him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />David commanded his workers to build houses for himself in Jerusalem. He also told them to set up a tent in which to put the Sacred Chest.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />He said, "Only the descendants of Levi are permitted to carry God's Sacred Chest, because they are the ones whom God chose to carry it and to serve him forever."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />David summoned all the people of Israel to come to Jerusalem. He wanted the Sacred Chest of Yahweh to be put in the place that he had made for it.</para>

<verse number="4" style="v" />He summoned the descendants of Aaron, who was the first Supreme Priest, and the descendants of Levi.

<para style="li1">

<verse number="5" style="v" />120 descendants of Kohath, who was Levi's second son, came, with Uriel their leader.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="6" style="v" />There were 220 descendants of Merari, Levi's third son, who came, with Asaiah their leader.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="7" style="v" />There were 130 descendants of Gershon, Levi's first son, who came, with Joel their leader.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="8" style="v" />Also, there were 200 people from Elizaphan's clan who came, with Shemaiah their leader.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />There were 80 people from Hebron's clan who came, with Eliel their leader.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />And there were 112 people from Uzziel's clan who came, with Amminadab their leader.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="11" style="v" />David summoned the priests Zadok and Abiathar and these descendants of Levi: Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />David said to them, "You are the leaders of the clans descended from Levi. You and the other descendants of Levi must purify yourselves, in order to be able to do this special work for Yahweh. You must bring the Sacred Chest of Yahweh, the God of us Israelites, up to the place that I have made for it here in Jerusalem.</para>

<verse number="13" style="v" />The first time that we tried to bring it, we did not ask Yahweh how we should carry it . You descendants of Levi were not the ones who carried it, so Yahweh our God punished us."

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />Then the priests and the descendants of Levi performed the rituals to purify themselves, in order that it would be proper for them to do the work of carrying the Sacred Chest of Yahweh, the God of the Israelite people.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />The descendants of Levi fastened poles to the Sacred Chest so that they could carry the Sacred Chest by fastening poles to it and carrying it on their shoulders, like Moses had commanded, and like Yahweh had said that they should.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />David told the leaders of the descendants of Levi to appoint some of their relatives to sing and play lyres, harps, and cymbals, and to sing joyful songs while they were carrying the Sacred Chest.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />So they appointed Heman and his relatives Asaph and Ethan. Heman was the son of Joel; Asaph was the son of Berekiah. Ethan, a descendant of Merari, was Kushaiah's son.

  <verse number="18" style="v" />There was also another group of descendants of Levi who were appointed: Zechariah, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, and two of the temple gatekeepers, Obed-Edom and Jeiel.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Heman, Asaph and Ethan sang, but also played bronze cymbals.

  <verse number="20" style="v" />Zechariah, Aziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah played lyres.

  <verse number="21" style="v" />Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-Edom, Jeiel and Azaziah played harps.</para>

<verse number="22" style="v" />Kenaniah, the leader of the descendants of Levi, directed the singing because he was very capable of doing that.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Berekiah and Elkanah were two of the men who guarded the Sacred Chest.

  <verse number="24" style="v" />The priests Shebaniah, Joshaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer were appointed to blow trumpets in front of the Sacred Chest. Obed-Edom and Jehiah also guarded the Sacred Chest.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="25" style="v" />David and the Israelite leaders and the officers who commanded 1,000 soldiers went to get the Sacred Chest. They went to bring it from Obed-Edom's house. They went very joyfully.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />God helped the descendants of Levi who carried the Sacred Chest of Yahweh; therefore David and the leaders sacrificed seven bulls and seven rams to thank him.</para>

<verse number="27" style="v" />All the descendants of Levi who carried the Sacred Chest, Kenaniah, the man who directed those who sang, all wore robes of fine white linen and sacred vests made of fine linen. David also wore a waistcloth made of white linen.

<verse number="28" style="v" />So all the of Israelite people joined in bringing the Sacred Chest up to Jerusalem. They shouted, blew horns and trumpets, and played cymbals, lyres, and harps.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="29" style="v" />While they were bringing the Sacred Chest into Jerusalem, Saul's daughter Michal watched them, looking out of a window. When she saw King David dancing and celebrating, she despised him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />They brought the Sacred Chest to Jerusalem and put it inside the Sacred Tent that David had told his workers to set up. Then they brought offerings to be completely burned on the altar and offerings to enable them to maintain fellowship with God.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />When David had finished presenting all those offerings, he asked Yahweh to bless the people.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />He gave a loaf of bread, some dates, and some raisins to every Israelite man and woman who was there.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Then David appointed some of the descendants of Levi to stand in front of the Sacred Tent in which the Sacred Chest had been placed, to lead the people who worshiped and thanked and praised Yahweh, the God of the Israelite people.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />Asaph, who played the cymbals, was their leader. Zechariah was his assistant. The other descendants of Levi who helped Asaph were Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-Edom, and Jeiel. They played lyres and harps.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Benaiah and Jahaziel were priests who blew trumpets frequently in front of the Sacred Tent in which was the Sacred Chest.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="7" style="v" />On that day, David gave to Asaph and his helpers this psalm to praise Yahweh:</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="8" style="v" />Thank God, and pray to him .</para>

<para style="q2">Tell the people of all nations what he has done.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />Sing to him; sing songs to praise him.</para>

<para style="q2">Tell about all his miraculous deeds.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />Be glad that you belong to him ;</para>

<para style="q2">those who want to know Yahweh better should rejoice.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="11" style="v" />Trust in Yahweh and in his power;</para>

<para style="q2">continually seek to get help from him.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="12" style="v" />Do not forget the wonderful things that he has done,</para>

<para style="q2">the miracles and the just laws that he has given to us.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="13" style="v" />We people are the descendants of his servant Jacob;</para>

<para style="q2">we are the people of Israel whom he has chosen.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="q1">

<verse number="14" style="v" />Yahweh is our God.</para>

<para style="q2">His just laws are known by people throughout the world.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="15" style="v" />He never forgets the agreements that he has made;</para>

<para style="q2">he made a promise that will last for a thousand generations.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="16" style="v" />That is the agreement that he made with Abraham,</para>

<para style="q2">and he repeated that agreement to Isaac.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="17" style="v" />It was an agreement for the Israelite people,</para>

<para style="q2">and he wanted that agreement to endure forever.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="18" style="v" />What he said was, "I will give the Canaan region to you,</para>

<para style="q2">to belong to you and your descendants forever."</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="q1">

<verse number="19" style="v" />He said that to them when there were only a few of them,</para>

<para style="q2">a tiny group of people who were living in that land like strangers;</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="20" style="v" />they continued to wander from one place to another,</para>

<para style="q2">from one kingdom to another.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="21" style="v" />But he did not allow others to oppress them,</para>

<para style="q2">and he warned kings by saying to them,</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="22" style="v" />"Do not harm the people whom I have chosen!</para>

<para style="q2">Do not harm my prophets!"</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="q1">

<verse number="23" style="v" />You people throughout the world, sing to Yahweh.</para>

<para style="q2">Every day proclaim to others that he has saved us.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="24" style="v" />Tell among the nations that he is great;</para>

<para style="q2">tell all the people-groups the marvelous things that he has done.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="25" style="v" />Yahweh is great, and he deserves to be praised very much.</para>

<para style="q2">He should be revered more than all the gods,</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="26" style="v" />because all the gods that the other people-groups worship are only idols,</para>

<para style="q2">but Yahweh is truly great; he created the skies.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="27" style="v" />He is glorious and majestic;</para>

<para style="q2">he is very powerful and joyful in his temple.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="q1">

<verse number="28" style="v" />You people in nations all over the world, praise Yahweh!</para>

<para style="q2">Praise Yahweh for his glorious power !</para>

<para style="q2">

<verse number="29" style="v" />Praise Yahweh like he  deserves to be praised.</para>

<para style="q1">Bring an offering and come to his temple.</para>

<para style="q2">Worship Yahweh because he is holy.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="30" style="v" />Everyone on the earth should tremble in front of Yahweh,</para>

<para style="q2">because he is majestic and holy.</para>

<para style="q2">He put the earth firmly in its place; and nothing ever will be able to move it.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="31" style="v" />Everything in the sky and on the earth should be happy.</para>

<para style="q2">People everywhere should say, "Yahweh is our king!"</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="32" style="v" />The oceans and all the creatures that are in the oceans should shout;</para>

<para style="q2">the fields and everything that is in them should rejoice.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="33" style="v" />When they do that, it will be as though the trees in the forest will sing joyfully in front of Yahweh.</para>

<para style="q2">That will happen when he comes to judge everyone on  the earth.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="q1">

<verse number="34" style="v" />Thank Yahweh, because everything that he does is good.</para>

<para style="q2">He faithfully loves us forever.</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="35" style="v" />Say to him, "God, you are the one who rescues us,</para>

<para style="q2">so gather us together and save us from the armies of other nations.</para>

<para style="q1">When you do that, we will thank you ,</para>

<para style="q2">and we will be happy to praise you."</para>

<para style="q1">

<verse number="36" style="v" />Praise Yahweh, the God of us Israelite people,</para>

<para style="q2">He has always existed, and he will exist forever.After the people finished singing that song, they all said "Amen!", and they praised Yahweh.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="37" style="v" />Then David left Asaph and the other members of his clan there in front of the tent in which Yahweh's Sacred Chest had been placed. He told them that they must do their work there every day.

  <verse number="38" style="v" />David also left Obed-Edom and 68 other descendants of Levi to work with them. Hosah and Obed-Edom guarded the entrances of the Sacred Tent.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="39" style="v" />David also told Zadok the Supreme Priest and the other priests who worked with him to remain in front of Yahweh's Sacred Tent, at the place where the Israelite people worshiped God there in Gibeon city.</para>

<verse number="40" style="v" />Every morning and every evening they burned offerings on the altar, obeying the rules which Yahweh had given to the Israelite people.

<verse number="41" style="v" />With them were Heman and Jeduthun and other descendants of Levi. They  were chosen to sing songs to praise Yahweh because he faithfully loves his people forever.

<verse number="42" style="v" />Heman and Jeduthun were appointed to play the trumpets and cymbals when the other descendants of Levi sang sacred songs. The sons of Jeduthun were appointed to guard the gates of the Sacred Tent.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="43" style="v" />Then all the people left. They all returned to their homes, and David returned home to ask Yahweh to bless his family.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />After David began to live in his palace, he said to the prophet Nathan, "It does not seem right that I am here living in a palace made of cedar wood, but Yahweh's Sacred Chest is kept inside a tent!"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="2" style="v" />Nathan replied to David, "Whatever you are thinking about doing, do it, because God is with you."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />But that night God spoke  to Nathan. He said,

  <verse number="4" style="v" />"Go and tell my servant David that this is what I, Yahweh, am saying to him: 'You are not the one who should build a temple for me to live in.

  <verse number="5" style="v" />I have not lived in any building, from the day that I brought the people of Israel up out of Egypt until now. Instead, I have lived in my Sacred Tent, moving from one place to another when the Israelites moved to other places.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Wherever I went with all the Israelites as they traveled, I never  them, "Why have you not built me a temple made of cedar wood?"~'</para>

<verse number="7" style="v" />Therefore, this is what you should say to my servant David: 'I, the Almighty Commander of the armies of angels, took you from a pasture where you were taking care of sheep, and I appointed you to be the ruler of my Israelite people.

<verse number="8" style="v" />I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have gotten rid of all your enemies who were in front of you. And now I will cause you to become very famous, as well-known as the names of the greatest men who have ever lived on the earth.

<verse number="9-10" style="v" />Formerly, during the time that I appointed leaders for my Israelite people, many violent groups oppressed them. But this will not happen anymore. I have chosen a place where my Israelite people can live peacefully and no one will disturb them anymore. I will give them rest from being attacked by their enemies. And I will defeat all your enemies.I declare to you that I, Yahweh, will enable your descendants to rule after you die.

<verse number="11" style="v" />When your life ends .

<verse number="12" style="v" />He is the one who will arrange for a temple to be built for me. And I will enable his descendants to be kings  of Israel forever.

<verse number="13" style="v" />I will be like a father to him, and it will be as though he is a son to me. I stopped loving Saul, the one who was the king before you became king, but I will never stop loving your son.

<verse number="14" style="v" />I will cause him to rule over my people .'~"

<para style="p">

  <verse number="15" style="v" />So Nathan reported to David everything that Yahweh had revealed to him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Then David went into the Sacred Tent and sat in the presence of Yahweh, and prayed this:"Yahweh my God, I am certainly not  worthy for you to have done of all these things for me, and my family is not worthy, either.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />And O God, now, in addition to everything else, you have spoken about what will happen to my descendants in the future for many generations. Yahweh my God, you have acted toward me as though I was the most important man on the earth!

  <verse number="18" style="v" />What more can I, David, say to you for honoring me? Although you know very well what I am like,</para>

<verse number="19" style="v" />Yahweh, for my sake and because it is what you wanted to do, you have done these great things for me, and you have revealed to me these things that you are promising to do.

<verse number="20" style="v" />Yahweh, you are great. There is no one like you. Only you are God, which is what we have always heard.

<verse number="21" style="v" />And there is no nation in the world like Israel . Israel is the only nation on the earth whose people you went out to rescue. You performed great and awesome miracles, rescuing our ancestors from being slaves in Egypt, expelling the people of other people-groups who were in Canaan.

<verse number="22" style="v" />You have caused us your Israelite people to belong to you forever, and you, Yahweh, have become our God!

<verse number="23" style="v" />And now Yahweh, I pray that you will cause the things that you have promised about me and my descendants  to be fulfilled forever, and do the things that you have said that you would do.

<verse number="24" style="v" />When that happens, you  of mine who will rule.

<verse number="25" style="v" />You, my God, have revealed to me that you will cause some of my descendants to become kings. So I am brave enough to pray like this to you.

<verse number="26" style="v" />Yahweh, you are God! You have promised to do these good things for me.

<verse number="27" style="v" />And now you, Yahweh, have promised to bless my descendants , in order that they will continue to rule forever. That will happen because you, Yahweh, are the one who has blessed them, and you will keep blessing them forever."

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Some time later, David's army attacked the army of Philistia and defeated them. They captured Gath city and the surrounding villages.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="2" style="v" />His army also defeated the army of the Moab people-group. The people were forced to accept David to be their ruler, and also to pay money each year to David's government, in order that David's army would protect them.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />David's army also fought against the army of Hadadezer, the king of the Zobah region in Syria near Hamath city, when Hadadezer was trying to establish control over the area near the Euphrates River.

  <verse number="4" style="v" />David's army captured 1,000 of Hadadezer's chariots, 7,000 chariot-drivers, and 20,000 soldiers. They hamstrung most of their horses; there were only 100 horses that they did not cripple.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />When the army of Syria came from Damascus city to help Hadadezer's army, David's soldiers killed 22,000 of them.

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Then David stationed groups of his soldiers in Damascus, and the people of Syria were forced to accept David to be their ruler, and to pay to David's government each year the payment that he demanded. And Yahweh enabled David's army to win battles everywhere they went.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="7" style="v" />David soldiers took the gold shields that were carried by the officers of Hadadezer's army and brought them to Jerusalem.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />They also brought from Tebah  and Cun, two towns that belonged to Hadadezer, a lot of bronze, which David's son Solomon later used to make the huge bronze basin and the pillars and other bronze items for the temple.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />When Tou, the king of Hamath city in Syria, heard that David's army had defeated the entire army of King Hadadezer,

  <verse number="10" style="v" />he sent his son Hadoram to King David, to greet him and congratulate him about his defeating Hadadezer's army, which had been fighting the army of Tou. Hadoram brought to David many items, Or: gifts made of gold, silver, and bronze.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="11" style="v" />King David dedicated those thngs to Yahweh, like he had done with the silver and gold that his soldiers had taken from the Edom and Moab people-groups, and from the Ammon people-group and from the people of Philistia, and from the descendants of Amalek.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />The army of David's army commander Abishai, whose mother was Zeruiah, killed 18,000 soldiers from Edom in the Salt Valley.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />Then David stationed groups of his soldiers there in Edom, and the people of Edom were forced to accept David to be their king and to pay money to David's government every year. And Yahweh enabled David's army to win battles wherever they went.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />David ruled over all the Israelite people, and he always did for them what was just and fair.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />Zeruiah's son Joab was the chief army commander. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was the record-keeper.

  <verse number="16" style="v" />Zadok the son of Ahitub and Ahimelech the son of Abiathar were the Supreme Priests. Shavsha was the official secretary.

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Benaiah the son of Jehoiada ruled over the Kereth and Peleth groups who were David's bodyguards. And David's sons were his most important officials.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Some time later, Nahash, the king of the Ammon people-group, died. Then his son Hanun became their king.

  <verse number="2" style="v" />When David heard about that, he thought to himself, "Nahash was kind to me, so I will be kind to his son." So David sent some officials there, to tell Hanun that he was sorry to hear that Hanun's father had died.</para>

<para style="p">But when David's officials came to Hanun in the land where the Ammon people-group lived,

  <verse number="3" style="v" />the leaders of the Ammon people-group said to Hanun, "Do you think that David is really to honor your father that King David is sending these men to say that he is sorry that your father died? We think that his men have come to look around our city in order to determine how his army can conquer us."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Hanun believed what they said; so he commanded some soldiers who seized the officials whom David had sent, and shaved off their beards, and insulted them by cutting off the lower part of their robes, and then sent them away.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />The officials were greatly humiliated. When David found out about what had happened to his officials, he sent some messengers to them to tell them, "Stay at Jericho until your beards have grown again, and then return home."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Then the leaders of the Ammon people-group realized that they had greatly insulted [IDI] David. So Hanun and some of his officials sent about 37,000 pounds of silver to hire chariots and chariot-drivers from the Aram-Naharaim, Aram-Maacah and Zobah regions northeast of Israel.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />They hired 32,000 chariots and chariot-drivers, as well as the kings of the Maacah and Tob regions and their armies. They came and set up their tents near Medeba town in Moab region. The soldiers from the Ammon people-group also marched out and stood in their positions at the entrance to their capital city, Rabbah.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />When David heard about that, he sent Joab and all his army.

  <verse number="9" style="v" />The soldiers of the Ammon people-group came out of their city and lined up for battle at the entrance to their city. Meanwhile, the other kings who had come with their armies stood in their positions in the open fields.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="10" style="v" />Joab saw that there were groups of enemy soldiers in front of his troops and behind his troops. So he selected some of the best Israelite troops and put them in positions to fight against the soldiers of Syria.

  <verse number="11" style="v" />He appointed his older brother Abishai to be the commander of his other soldiers and he told them to stand in their positions in front of the army of the Ammon people-group.</para>

<verse number="12" style="v" />Joab said to them, "If the soldiers from Syria are too strong for us to defeat them, then your soldiers must come and help us. But if the soldiers from the Ammon people-group are too strong for you to defeat them, then my soldiers will come and help your men.

<verse number="13" style="v" />We must be strong our God. I will pray that Yahweh will do what he considers to be good."

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />So Joab and his troops advanced to fight the army of Syria, and the soldiers from Syria ran away from them.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />And when the soldiers of the Ammon people-group saw that the soldiers from Syria were running away, they also started to run away from Abishai and his army, and they retreated back inside the city. So Joab and his army returned to Jerusalem.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />After the leaders of the army of Syria realized that they had been defeated by the army of Israel, they sent messengers to another part of Syria on the east side of the Euphrates river, and brought troops from there to the battle area, with Shophach, the commander of Hadadezer's army, leading them.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />When David heard about that, he gathered all the Israelite soldiers, and they crossed the Jordan River. They advanced and took their battle positions to attack the army of Syria.</para>

<verse number="18" style="v" />But the army of Syria ran away from the soldiers of Israel. However, David's soldiers killed 7,000 of their chariot-drivers and 40,000 other soldiers. They also killed Shophach, their army commander.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="19" style="v" />When the kings who had been ruled by Hadadezer realized that they had been defeated by the Israelite army, they made peace with David, and agreed to allow him to rule them.</para>

<para style="p">So the rulers of Syria did not want to help the rulers of the Ammon people-group anymore.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />In that region, kings usually went with their armies to fight their enemies in the springtime. But the following year, David did not do that. Instead, he stayed in Jerusalem, and he sent his commander Joab to lead the army. Joab took his troops. They crossed the Jordan River and ruined the land of the Ammon people-group. Then they went to Rabbah, the capital city, and surrounded it. But David stayed in Jerusalem for a while. But later he took more troops and went to help Joab. Their armies attacked Rabbah and destroyed it.</para>

<verse number="2" style="v" />Then David took the crown from the head of the king of Rabbah , and it had many very valuable stones fastened to it. They also took many other valuable things from the city.

<verse number="3" style="v" />Then they brought the people out of the city and forced them to work for their army, using saws and iron picks and axes. David's soldiers did this in all the cities of the Ammon people-group. Then David and all of his army returned to Jerusalem.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="4" style="v" />Later, David's army fought a battle with the army of Philistia, at Gezer city. During the battle Sibbecai, from Hushah clan, killed Sippai, one of the descendants of the of the Rapha giants. So the armies of Philistia were defeated.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />In another battle against the soldiers of Philistia, Elhanan, the son of Jair, killed Lahmi, the younger brother of the giant Goliath from Gath town, who had a spear which was as thick as a weaver's rod.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />There was another battle near Gath. A huge man was there who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot. He was descended from the Rapha giants.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />When he made fun of the soldiers of Israel, Jonathan, the son of David's older brother Shimea, killed him.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Those were some of the descendants of the Rapha giants who had lived in Gath, who were killed  by David and his soldiers.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Satan decided to cause the Israelite people to have trouble. So he incited David to find out how many men in Israel were able to be in the army.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="2" style="v" />So David commanded Joab and the other army commanders, "Count all the men in Israel who are able to be in the army. Start at Beersheba town in the south and go all the way to Dan city in the north. Then come back and report to me, in order that I may know how many men there are."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="3" style="v" />But Joab replied, "Your majesty, even if Yahweh allowed us to have a hundred times as many soldiers as we have now, you would  cause all the people of Israel to be guilty of sinning."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="4" style="v" />But David would not change his mind. So Joab and his soldiers went everywhere in Israel and in Judah, and counted the people. Then they returned to Jerusalem,

  <verse number="5" style="v" />and they reported to David that there were 1,100,000 men in Israel who could be in the army, and 470,000 in Judah.</para>

<verse number="6" style="v" />Joab did not count the men from the tribes of Levi and Benjamin, because he was disgusted with what the king had commanded.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="7" style="v" />David's command to count the people caused God to become angry, so he told David that he had decided to punish the people of Israel.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />Then David prayed, saying, "Yahweh, what I did was very foolish. I have sinned greatly by what I have done. So now I plead with you, please forgive me."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="9" style="v" />Then Yahweh said to Gad, David's prophet,

  <verse number="10" style="v" />"Go and tell this to David: 'I am allowing you to choose one of three things to punish you. I will do whichever one you choose.'~"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="11" style="v" />So Gad went to David and said to him, "This is what Yahweh says: 'You can choose one of these punishments:

  <verse number="12" style="v" />three years of famine in Israel, or three months during which your armies will run away from their enemies who will attack them with swords, or three days during which I will send my angel to cause many people in the country to die because of a plague.' So, you must decide what I will say to answer Yahweh, the one who sent me."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="13" style="v" />David replied to Gad, "I am very distressed. But allow Yahweh to punish  me, because he is very merciful. Do not allow humans to punish me, because they will not be merciful."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />So Yahweh sent a plague on the people of Israel, and 70,000 of them died because of it.

  <verse number="15" style="v" />And God sent an angel to destroy the people in Jerusalem by the plague. But when the angel was standing at the ground where Araunah, from the Jebus people-group, threshed grain, Yahweh saw all the suffering that the people had endured, and he was grieved. So he said to the angel, "Stop what you are doing [IDI]! That is enough [IDI]!"</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="16" style="v" />David looked up and saw the angel whom Yahweh had sent, standing between the sky and the ground. The angel had a sword in his hand that was pointed toward Jerusalem. Then David and the elders of the city, who were wearing clothes made of rough sackcloth, prostrated themselves on the ground.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />David said to God, "I am  done anything that is wrong. So Yahweh my God, punish [IDI] me and my family, but do not allow this plague to continue to cause your people to become sick and die."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="18" style="v" />Then the angel who was sent by Yahweh told Gad to go up to the place where Araunah threshed grain and tell David to build an altar to worship Yahweh there.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />So after Gad told David, he obeyed the message that Yahweh  had given to Gad, and he went up there.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="20" style="v" />While Araunah was threshing some wheat, he turned and saw the angel. His four sons who were with him also saw the angel, and they hid themselves.</para>

<verse number="21" style="v" />Then David approached. When Araunah saw him, he left the place where he was threshing grain and prostrated himself, with his face touching the ground.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="22" style="v" />David said to him, "Please sell me this place for threshing in order that I can build an altar here to worship Yahweh, in order that he will stop this plague. I will pay the full price."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="23" style="v" />Araunah replied, "Take it! Your majesty, do whatever you want to. I will give you the oxen that thresh the grain for an offering to be completely burned on the altar. And I will give you the threshing boards to use as wood on the altar, and I will give you flour for a flour offering. I will give all those things to you."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="24" style="v" />But the king said to Araunah, "No, I will not take these things as a gift. I will pay you the full price for it. I will not take what belongs to you, and offer sacrifices that have cost me nothing and offer them to Yahweh to be completely burned on the altar."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="25" style="v" />So David paid to Araunah 600 pieces of gold for the whole area.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />David built an altar to worship Yahweh there, and he offered sacrifices to be completely burned on the altar and sacrifices to restore fellowship with Yahweh. David prayed to Yahweh, and Yahweh answered by sending a fire from heaven to burn up the offerings on the altar.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="27" style="v" />Then Yahweh spoke to the angel, and told him to put his sword back into its sheath. So the angel did that.</para>

<verse number="28" style="v" />And when David saw that Yahweh had answered him there at the place where Araunah threshed grain and had ended the plague, he offered sacrifices there.

<verse number="29" style="v" />Yahweh's Sacred Tent, which Moses had commanded to be set up in the desert, and the altar for burning sacrifices completely, were at that time on a hill at Gibeon city.

<verse number="30" style="v" />But David did not want to go there to request God to tell him what he wanted David to do, because he was afraid that the angel sent from Yahweh might strike him with his sword.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />Then David said, "Here, at the edge of Jerusalem, is where we will build the temple for our God Yahweh, and where we will make the altar for burning the offerings that the Israelite people will bring."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="2" style="v" />So David commanded that the foreigners who lived in Israel must gather together. When they did that, he appointed some of those men to cut huge stones from the quarries and to smooth their surfaces, to be used to build the temple of God.</para>

<verse number="3" style="v" />David provided a large amount of iron for making nails and hinges for the doors in the gates of the temple. He also provided a huge amount of bronze for making various utensils; and because there was a huge amount of it, no one could weigh it all.

<verse number="4" style="v" />He also provided money for buying a large amount of cedar logs. Because there was a huge number of them, no one counted them. Those were logs that men from Tyre and Sidon cities sent to David.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="5" style="v" />David provided all those things because he thought, "My son Solomon is still young and he does not know what he needs to know about building buildings, and the temple of Yahweh must be magnificent. It must be a glorious building that will become famous, and people throughout the world must consider it to be glorious, Or: splendid. So now I will begin to prepare for it to be built, and Solomon will be responsible for finishing it." So David collected a great amount of building materials before he died.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Then David summoned his son Solomon, and told him that he should arrange for a temple to be built for Yahweh, the God whom the Israelites worshiped.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />He said to him, "I wanted [IDI] to build a temple to honor  Yahweh, my God.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />But Yahweh told a prophet to tell me, 'You have killed many men .</para>

<verse number="9" style="v" />But you will have a son who will be king of Israel after you die. He will be a man who is peaceful and quiet, not a man who kills others. And I will cause that there will be peace between him and his enemies who are in all the nearby lands. His name will be Solomon, which sounds like the word for peace. During the time that he is king, people in Israel will be peaceful and safe.

<verse number="10" style="v" />He is the one who will arrange for a temple to be built to honor me .'

<para style="p">

  <verse number="11" style="v" />So now, my son, I hope that Yahweh will help you, and enable you to be successful in arranging for building the temple of Yahweh, your God, which is what he said that you would do.

  <verse number="12" style="v" />I also hope that he will enable you to be wise and to understand what you need to know, and enable you to obey his laws while you rule over Israel.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />If you carefully obey all the laws and regulations and courageous. Do not be afraid of anything, and do not become discouraged!</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="14" style="v" />I have tried hard to provide materials for building the temple of Yahweh. I have provided nearly 4,000 tons of gold, and nearly 40,000 tons of silver. I have also provided a very large amount of iron and bronze; no one has been able to weigh it all. I have also gathered lumber and stone for the walls of the temple, but you may need to get some more of those things.</para>

<verse number="15" style="v" />There are many men in Israel who have good ability to cut big stones for making stone walls, and carpenters, and men who are very skilled at making various kinds of things.

<verse number="16" style="v" />There are many men who know how to make things from gold and silver and bronze and iron. So now I say to you, begin the work of building the temple, and I hope with you."

<para style="p">

  <verse number="17" style="v" />Then David commanded that all the Israelite leaders must assist Solomon. He said to them,

  <verse number="18" style="v" />"Yahweh our God is certainly with. He has enabled my army to conquer [IDI] them, so now Yahweh and my people control them.

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Now you must obey Yahweh with your entire inner beings. Help Solomon to arrange for building the temple for Yahweh God, in order that you can bring the Sacred Chest that contains the Ten Commandments and the other sacred items that belong to God into the temple that you will build to honor Yahweh."</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />David was a very old man  when he appointed his son Solomon to be the next king.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="2" style="v" />David gathered the leaders of Israel and the priests and other descendants of Levi.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />He commanded some of his officials to count the descendants of Levi who were at least thirty years old, and they found out that there were 38,000 of them.</para>

<verse number="4" style="v" />Then David said, "From those 38,000 men, I want 24,000 of them to supervise the work at the temple of Yahweh, and I want 6,000 of them to be officials and judges.

<verse number="5" style="v" />I want 4,000 to be guards at the gates, and 4,000 to praise Yahweh, using the musical instruments that I have provided for them."

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />David divided the descendants of Levi into three groups; each group consisted of men who were descendants of one of the three sons of LeviGershon, Kohath, and Merari.</para>

<para style="s2">The descendants of Gershon</para>

<verse number="7" style="v" />From the descendants of Gershon there were Ladan and Shimei.

<para style="li1">

<verse number="8" style="v" />There were three sons of Ladan: Jehiel was the oldest, and his younger brothers Zetham and Joel.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />There were three of the sons of Shimei: Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran.</para>

<para style="li2">They were all leaders of the clans of Ladan.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />There were four men who were other sons of Shimei:</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="11" style="v" />Jahath, who was his oldest son, and his younger brothers Ziza, Jeush, and Beriah.</para>

<para style="li2">Jeush and Beriah did not have many sons, so they were counted as though they were one family.</para>

<para style="s2">The descendants of Kohath</para>

<verse number="12" style="v" />Kohath had four sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

<para style="li1">

<verse number="13" style="v" />There were two sons of Amram: Aaron and Moses.</para>

<para style="li2">Aaron and his descendants were set apart to dedicate the very holy things, to offer sacrifices to Yahweh, to serve in his presence, and to declare to the people what Yahweh  would do to bless them. They were to do those things forever.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="14" style="v" />The sons of Moses, the man who served God well, were counted as part of the tribe of Levi.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="15" style="v" />The sons of Moses were Gershom and Eliezer.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="16" style="v" />The oldest son of Gershom was Shubael.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="17" style="v" />Rehabiah was the oldest son of Eliezer.</para>

<para style="li2">Eliezer had no other sons, but Rehabiah had many sons.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="18" style="v" />The oldest son of Izhar was Shelomith.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="19" style="v" />Hebron had four sons.</para>

<para style="li2">Jeriah was his oldest son, and his younger brothers were Amariah, Jahaziel, and Jekameam.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="20" style="v" />Uzziel had two sons.</para>

<para style="li2">Micah was the oldest son, and his younger brother was Isshiah.</para>

<para style="s2">The descendants of Merari</para>

<verse number="21" style="v" />Merari had two sons: Mahli and Mushi.

<para style="li2">The sons of Mahli were Eleazar and Kish.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="22" style="v" />Eleazar had no sons; he had only daughters. So their cousins, the sons of Kish, married them.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="23" style="v" />The three sons of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="p">

  <verse number="24" style="v" />Those were the descendants of Levi, whose names were listed according to their families. Each person who was at least twenty years old was listed. They all worked in the temple of Yahweh.

  <verse number="25" style="v" />David had said previously, "Yahweh, the God to whom we Israelite people belong, has enabled us to have peace, and he has come to live in Jerusalem forever.

  <verse number="26" style="v" />Therefore, the descendants of Levi no longer need to carry the Sacred Tent and the items used in the work there."</para>

<verse number="27" style="v" />Obeying the final instructions of David before he died, instructions for doing this work at the temple, they counted only the descendants of Levi who were at least twenty years old.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="28" style="v" />The work of those descendants of Levi was to assist the descendants of Aaron in their work in the temple of Yahweh: to be in charge of the temple courtyards and the side rooms, the ceremonies for purifying all the sacred things, and to do other work at the temple.

  <verse number="29" style="v" />They were also in charge of the loaves of bread on display before God, the loaves that were placed each week on the table in the temple, the flour for the flour offerings, the wafers that were made without yeast, and the measuring the ingredients and mixing them and baking that bread and those wafers.</para>

<verse number="30" style="v" />They were also told to stand every morning at the temple and thank Yahweh and praise him. They were also required to do the same thing every evening.

<verse number="31" style="v" />And they were to do the same thing whenever offerings that were to be completely burned on the altar were presented to Yahweh on Sabbath days and during the new moon celebrations and other religious festivals. They were told how many of them should be there and what they should do each time.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="32" style="v" />So the descendants of Levi did the work that was assigned to them by their fellow Israelites who were descendants of Aaron. They did that work at the Sacred Tent and in the holy place inside the tent, and later at the temple.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />These are the groups of the descendants of Aaron the first Supreme Priest: Aaron's four sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="2" style="v" />But Nadab and Abihu died before their father died, and they had no children. So their younger brothers Eleazar and Ithamar became the priests.

  <verse number="3" style="v" />Zadok, who was a descendant of Eleazar, and Ahimelech, who was a descendant of Ithamar, helped David to separate the family groups into two groups. Each group had certain duties.</para>

<verse number="4" style="v" />There were more leaders among the descendants of Eleazar than there were among the descendants of Ithamar. So they appointed sixteen leaders from Eleazar's descendants and eight leaders from Ithamar's descendants.

<verse number="5" style="v" />There were temple officials and priests who were there, including descendants of both Eleazar and Ithamar, to make sure that the work was divided fairly. So they decided what work each group would do by casting lots.

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />Shemaiah, the son of Nethanel, who was a descendant of Levi, wrote down the names of the leaders of each group while David and his officials were watching. Zadok, the Supreme Priest, and Ahimelech his assistant, and the leaders of the families of the priests and of the families of the other descendants of Levi also watched.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="li1">

<verse number="7" style="v" />Jehoiarib was the first one whose name was selected by casting lots.</para>

<para style="li1">Next Jedaiah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="8" style="v" />Next, Harim was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Seorim was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />Next, Malkijah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Mijamin was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />Next, Hakkoz was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Abijah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="11" style="v" />Next, Jeshua was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Shecaniah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="12" style="v" />Next, Eliashib was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Jakim was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="13" style="v" />Next, Huppah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Jeshebeab was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="14" style="v" />Next, Bilgah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Immer was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="15" style="v" />Next, Hezir was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Happizzez was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="16" style="v" />Next, Pethahiah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Jehezkel was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="17" style="v" />Next, Jakin was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Gamul was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="18" style="v" />Next, Delaiah was selected.</para>

<para style="li1">Next, Maaziah was selected.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="19" style="v" />Those were the men who were chosen to be the leaders of the groups that would serve in the temple, obeying the regulations that were set down by Aaron, regulations which Yahweh, the God to whom we Israelite people belong, had given to him.</para>

<verse number="20" style="v" />This is a list of some of the other descendants of Levi:

<para style="li1">From the sons of Amram there was Shubael.</para>

<para style="li2">From the sons of Shubael there was Jehdeiah.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="21" style="v" />From Rehabiah the son of Eleazar there was Isshiah, his oldest son.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="22" style="v" />From the descendants of Kohath's son Izhar there was Shelomoth.</para>

<para style="li2">From the descendants of Shelomoth there was Jahath.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="23" style="v" />From the descendants of Kohath's son Hebron there was his oldest son Jeriah and Jeriah's younger brothers Amariah, Jahaziel, and Jekameam.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="24" style="v" />From the descendants of Kohath's son Uzziel there was Micah.</para>

<para style="li2">From the descendants of Micah there was Shamir.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="25" style="v" />And Micah's younger brother was Isshiah.</para>

<para style="li2">From the descendants of Isshiah was Zechariah.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="26" style="v" />The sons of Merari were Mahli, Mushi, and Jaaziah.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="27" style="v" />From the descendants of Jaaziah there were Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="28" style="v" />Mahli's son Eleazar did not have any sons.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="29" style="v" />From the descendants of Kish there was his son Jerahmeel.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="30" style="v" />The sons of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="p">Those were descendants of Levi who were listed according to the leaders of their families.

  <verse number="31" style="v" />The jobs they would do were decided by casting lots while King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the leaders of he families of the priests and the descendants of Levi watched. The jobs that were given to the families of each oldest brother and each youngest brother were equal.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />David and some of the temple officials  chose some of the descendants of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to be in charge of the preaching, and to play harps and lyres and cymbals. This is a list of the men whom they chose for that work:</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="2" style="v" />From the sons of Asaph they chose Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Aserelah. Asaph supervised them. And the king appointed Asaph to preach.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="3" style="v" />From the sons of Jeduthun they chose six men: Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah. Jeduthun supervised them and also preached, playing his harp while he thanked and praised Yahweh.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="4" style="v" />From the sons of Heman they chose Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shubael, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti-Ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.

<verse number="5" style="v" />They were all sons of Heman, who was King David's prophet. God promised to cause Heman to be strong, so altogether, God have him fourteen sons and three daughters.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="6" style="v" />All those men were supervised by their fathers while they played music in the temple of Yahweh. They played cymbals, lyres, and harps. And their fathersAsaph, Jeduthun and Hemanwere supervised by the king.

  <verse number="7" style="v" />Those men and their relatives were all trained and skilled for playing musical instruments in the temple. That was their work for Yahweh. Including their relatives, there were 288 of them.

  <verse number="8" style="v" />All of them, including ones who were young and those who were old, cast lots to determine what work they would do.</para>

<para style="b" />

<para style="li1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />From the family of Asaph, the first ones selected were Joseph and 12 of his sons and relatives.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />Next, Gedaliah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="11" style="v" />Next, Zaccur and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="12" style="v" />Next, Nethaniah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="13" style="v" />Next, Bukkiah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="14" style="v" />Next, Jesarelah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="15" style="v" />Next, Jeshaiah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="16" style="v" />Next, Mattaniah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="17" style="v" />Next, Shimei and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="18" style="v" />Next, Azarel and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="19" style="v" />Next, Hashabiah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="20" style="v" />Next, Shubael and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="21" style="v" />Next, Mattithiah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="22" style="v" />Next, Jerimoth and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="23" style="v" />Next, Hananiah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="24" style="v" />Next, Joshbekashah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="25" style="v" />Next, Hanani and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="26" style="v" />Next, Mallothi and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="27" style="v" />Next, Eliathah and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="28" style="v" />Next, Hothir and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="29" style="v" />Next, Giddalti and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="30" style="v" />Next, Mahazioth and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="31" style="v" />Next, Romamti-Ezer and 12 of his sons and relatives were selected.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="1" style="v" />This is a list of the groups of men who guarded the temple gates:</para>

<para style="li1">From the descendants of Korah, there was Meshelemiah, the son of Kore, who was one of the sons of Asaph.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="2" style="v" />The oldest son of Meshelemiah was Zechariah. His other sons were Jediael, Zebadiah, Jathniel,

<verse number="3" style="v" />Elam, Jehohanan, and Eliehoenai.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="4" style="v" />Another guard was Obed-Edom.</para>

<para style="li2">His oldest son was Shemaiah. His other sons were Jehozabad, Joah, Sacar, Nethanel,

<verse number="5" style="v" />Ammiel, Issachar, and Peullethai. It was because God had blessed him that he had many sons.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="6" style="v" />Obed-Edom's son Shemaiah also had sons. They were leaders in their father's family because they were capable of doing many things well.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="7" style="v" />The sons of Shemaiah were Othni, Rephael, Obed, and Elzabad. Shemaiah's relatives Elihu and Semakiah were also capable men.</para>

<para style="li2">

<verse number="8" style="v" />All of those descendants of Obed-Edom and their sons and relatives were capable people and strong workers. Altogether there were 62 of them.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="9" style="v" />Another guard was Meshelemiah. He and his sons and relatives were also capable people. There were 18 of them altogether.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="10" style="v" />Another guard was Hosah's son Shimri, a descendant of Merari. Hosah appointed Shimri to be the leader, even though he was not Hosah's oldest son.

<verse number="11" style="v" />Hosah's other sons were Hilkiah, Tabaliah, and Zechariah. Altogether there were 13 sons and relatives of Hosah.</para>

<para style="p">

  <verse number="12" style="v" />Those men were leaders of the groups of men who guarded the gates of the temple. They worked at the temple like their relatives did.

  <verse number="13" style="v" />By casting lots, the leader of each family chose one gate for their group to guard. All of them, including young men and old men , cast lots.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="14" style="v" />Shelemiah's group was selected to guard the East Gate.</para>

<para style="li1">The group of Shelemiah's son Zechariah, who was a wise counselor, was selected to guard the North Gate.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="15" style="v" />Then Obed-Edom's group was selected to guard the South Gate, and his sons were selected to guard the entrances to the temple storerooms.</para>

<para style="li1">

<verse number="16" style="v" />Then Shuppim's group and Hosah's group were selected to guard the West Gate and the Shalleketh Gate on the upper road to the temple.</para>

<para style="p">The work for the guards was divided evenly.</para>

<verse number="17" style="v" />Each day there were six descendants of Levi who guarded the East Gate, four who guarded the North Gate, four who guarded the South Gate, and two at a time who guarded the entrances to the storerooms.

<verse number="18" style="v" />At the West gate there were two men who guarded the courtyard and four who guarded the road outside the courtyard.

<para style="p">
